author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden Administration Adds 37 Chinese Companies to Forced Labor List
description: The administration announced it would penalize its largest-ever batch of companies linked to Xinjiang, including major suppliers of critical minerals and textiles.
content: The Biden administration said on Tuesday that it would block imports from more than three dozen Chinese companies, citing their alleged ties to forced labor in the Xinjiang region of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Ryan
title: Pregnant and Abused, These Young Women Fight Back With Witchcraft
description: Grady Hendrix’s new novel, “Witchcraft for Wayward Girls,” is a timely look at the mistreatment of women, with a dose of horror, monsters and magic.
content: What is a wayward girl? In American history, waywardism was a capacious category, large enough to contain all of our anxieties about young women and transform them into a network of laws, courthouses, prisons, asylums and extralegal institutions that have, since the time of the Civil War, targeted girls over infractions that are ignored or even celebrated in boys. Wayward girls were a dangerous rot in the moral heart of the country, we were told, and every time a young woman wore pants or had sex or spoke back to her parents, she took another step down a road that could only end in syphilis, sex work and bastard children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Minnesota’s Legislative Session Opens Chaotically as House Democrats Boycott
description: A one-seat Republican majority in the Statehouse and a looming special election made for a tense start to a new era of divided government.
content: Minnesota’s new legislative session began chaotically on Tuesday as House Democrats refused to show up at the State Capitol for the opening day amid an escalating dispute with Republicans over control of the chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: As Trump Returns, Murphy Plans to Protect Abortion Access in New Jersey
description: In his State of the State address, Gov. Philip Murphy also said he would ban cellphones in schools and overhaul the state’s 10 most dangerous intersections.
content: As he prepares for his final year as governor of New Jersey, Philip D. Murphy on Tuesday proposed banning cellphones in schools and disclosed plans to blunt any additional limits on abortion access by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood’s Filmmaking Continues Despite L.A. Wildfires
description: Because of costs, few movies are shot locally, leaving the industry in a surreal spot: reeling from personal loss with much of the business untouched.
content: Over the past week, as eight wildfires destroyed vast portions of its home metropolis, Hollywood found itself violently impacted — and, at the same time, barely impacted at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Sequels and Remakes
description: When it comes to movies, do you prefer original stories or reboots of your old favorites?
content: Do you enjoy watching movies? When you choose something new to watch, are you more likely to go for an original, or instead for a sequel or remake of a film you already know and love?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Preston Clark Steps Into the Spotlight at Bar Mercer
description: Oases takes an Ayurvedic approach to cooking, the chef Francis Mallmann comes to New York and more restaurant news.
content: The spotlight is finally catching the chef Preston Clark. He is a son of Patrick Clark, a chef who died at 42, notable for his stint at Tavern on the Green some 35 years ago and his influence on new American cooking. Now, after 11 years at John McDonald’s Lure Fishbar, Preston Clark has taken the reins as the executive chef of the moody new bar and restaurant that replaces Mr. McDonald’s Bar Tulix. The chef’s menu, with blackboard specials and items that flatter a classic drink, features filet mignon au poivre, chicken liver mousse, fish and chips, and pigs in blankets. “Pigs in blankets transcend class, which is what I like about them,” Mr. Clark said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: My All-Nighter in a Vanishing World: the 24-Hour Diner
description: New York may be losing its identity as the city that doesn’t sleep, but the motley guests at Kellogg’s Diner show the spirit is still wide awake.
content: You never know who you might meet in the wee, small hours of an all-night diner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: The Wait, the Worry and the Fear
description: Matt Stevens, an arts and culture reporter based in Los Angeles, finds a personal connection between fires past and present.
content: It was 2007, and my very first week away from home. I had barely tacked a Playbill over my bed in a dorm room at the University of California, Los Angeles, when I heard from my parents. A wildfire was racing through the hills near my San Diego suburb. Just a few days before, I had said a teary goodbye to my parents to start life on my own. Now, they were evacuating — and I was terrified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall and Thea Traff
title: Where to Find Pink Sand, Palm Trees and Robert De Niro
description: The actor has long had a second career as a hotelier and restaurateur. Now, he and his partners are planning to open a luxury inn on the Caribbean island of Barbuda.
content: It’s odd enough to find yourself traveling by helicopter from one Caribbean island to another for lunch, even if your destination is Nobu Barbuda, an outpost of the famous restaurant plunked down on a semi-deserted beach. It’s odd in a different way to arrive and spot the 81-year-old actor Robert De Niro dressed in a pair of shorts and a tiny bucket hat, waiting for you at a table in the back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage, Jonathan Swan and Theodore Schleifer
title: Elon Musk Is Expected to Use Office Space in the White House Complex
description: The location suggests that Mr. Musk, who owns companies with billions of dollars in contracts with the federal government, will continue to have remarkable access to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
content: Elon Musk is expected to use office space in the White House complex as he launches the so-called Department of Government Efficiency, which aims to slash government spending in the Trump administration, according to two people briefed on the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain’s Anticorruption Minister Resigns
description: Tulip Siddiq, the niece of former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh, had been named in an embezzlement investigation in the Asian country in December.
content: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain suffered a new blow on Tuesday when his anticorruption minister, Tulip Siddiq, quit her post weeks after being named in an embezzlement investigation in Bangladesh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Ukraine Launches ‘Massive’ Drone Attacks Inside Russia, Officials Say
description: The barrage appeared to be one of the largest recent assaults in Ukraine’s campaign to damage Russia’s war machine on its home territory.
content: Ukraine carried out “massive” drone strikes on several regions of Russia overnight, local officials there said on Tuesday, in what appeared to be one of the largest recent assaults in Kyiv’s campaign to cripple Russia’s war machine on its home turf.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Carnage in Kursk, for a Costly Bargaining Chip
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 14, 2025.
content: “We’re holding on, destroying, destroying, destroying — so much that it’s hard to even comprehend.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: New Administration to Take Over in Challenging Era for the Pentagon
description: The incoming defense secretary will face several challenges, including the war in Ukraine and the turmoil in the Middle East.
content: The next defense secretary will face myriad major challenges: the war in Ukraine, turmoil in the Middle East and rising military threat from China. And then there’s what lies closer to home: possibly deploying U.S. troops to the southwestern border to address immigration concerns, and revitalizing America’s military industrial base to confront global adversaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker and Dzvinka Pinchuk
title: For These Teenagers in Ukraine, Hope Arrived at the Stage Door
description: The students in a summer acting course performed a play set in America, called, “It’s okay!” And it gave them hope that their lives would be OK, too.
content: The teacher needed teenagers for her summer acting class in Kyiv, which would end with the performance of an original play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Senate Hearings for Trump’s Cabinet Picks Have Begun. Here’s the Schedule.
description: Selections for attorney general, secretary of homeland security, secretary of state and Treasury secretary are among those set to have hearings this week.
content: The Senate has scheduled hearings for a dozen of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks for some of the most significant positions in his new government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Speaker Orders Capitol Hill Flags Raised for Inauguration
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump had complained that flags were scheduled to fly at half-staff — a symbol of mourning for former President Jimmy Carter — on the day of his inauguration.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson on Tuesday announced that American flags at the Capitol would be temporarily raised on Monday for President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, effectively defying a presidential order put in place last month to mourn the death of former President Jimmy Carter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: New Obesity Definition Challenges Current Use of B.M.I.
description: An international commission made the case for focusing on body fat quantity and the illnesses people experience.
content: Obesity should be assessed in a way that goes beyond the standard measure of body mass index, or B.M.I., according to a new definition of the condition released by an international commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fu and Meaghan Tobin
title: ‘Red Note,’ a Chinese App, Is Dominating Downloads, Thanks to TikTok Users
description: To show how little they care about TikTok’s ties to Beijing, people in the United States are downloading one of China’s most popular apps.
content: Manimatana Lee spent the past five years building one of the hottest commodities on the internet: a group of people who reliably watch her videos on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Special Counsel Report Says Trump Would Have Been Convicted in Election Case
description: The report, which said the special counsel’s office stood “fully behind” the merits of the prosecution, amounted to an extraordinary rebuke of the president-elect.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel who indicted President-elect Donald J. Trump on charges of illegally seeking to cling to power after losing the 2020 election, said in a final report released early Tuesday that the evidence would have been sufficient to convict Mr. Trump in a trial, had his 2024 election victory not made it impossible for the prosecution to continue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Readers Pick the Songs That Defined Their Year
description: Hear songs from Ana Moura, the Orlons and Colin Hay that defined 2024 for readers.
content: No matter what year it is, I know this much to be true: Amplifier readers always deliver when I ask for song recommendations. At the end of 2024, I asked you to submit a song that defined your year — not a new song that was released in 2024, but one that had boomeranged back through time and took on a particular resonance for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Four Takeaways From the Special Counsel’s Report on the Trump Election Case
description: Jack Smith wrote that Donald Trump would have been convicted had the case been allowed to proceed and explained why he didn’t pursue charges of incitement of the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol.
content: The Justice Department released a 137-page volume early Tuesday morning laying out the details of the investigation that the former special counsel Jack Smith conducted into President-elect Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn his loss in the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Democrats Say F.B.I. Did Not Interview Critical Witnesses About Pete Hegseth
description: The bureau did not interview an ex-wife of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary before the findings on his background check were presented to senators.
content: Senate Democrats on Monday said that an F.B.I. background check on Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon, omitted key details on major allegations against him, in part because it did not include interviews with critical witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Mike Baker, Christopher Flavelle, Shannon M. Lin, Alex Stern, Sydney Harper, Lynsea Garrison, Olivia Natt, Liz O. Baylen, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: Could the L.A. Fires Have Been Stopped Sooner?
description: California has focused on fortifying communities against wildfires. Why was it not enough?
content: Warning: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Pete Hegseth’s Preposterous Selection
description: It should be derailed after today’s hearing. I doubt it will.
content: A telling moment in the supremely depressing Senate confirmation hearing for Pete Hegseth, the Fox News personality who is Donald Trump’s pick for defense secretary, came right at the beginning, when the former Republican senator Norm Coleman introduced him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Auto Fire Joins List of California Blazes
description: The new fire, in Ventura County northwest of Los Angeles, covers 56 acres and is 0 percent contained, officials said.
content: Firefighters are tracking a new blaze in Southern California, the Auto fire, which began burning Monday evening in Ventura County, northwest of downtown Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Robinhood Is Fined $45 Million Over a New Set of Securities Violations
description: The upstart brokerage agreed to pay the Securities and Exchange Commission for failing to protect sensitive customer data, among other infractions.
content: Robinhood was hit with $45 million in fresh fines from the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday, the latest reprimand that the crypto-favorite brokerage has received from regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Biden Promised to ‘Turn the Page’ on Trump. What Went Wrong?
description: Jake Sullivan, Biden’s national security adviser, looks back on the hopes and realities of Bidenism.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: A Superb, Speedy Chicken
description: Ali Slagle’s ginger-lime chicken, bright and bolstering, is ready in just 15 minutes.
content: Hello and a belated happy New Year. A big thanks to Ali Slagle and Mia Leimkuhler, my colleagues who covered for me over the holidays and wrote to you about slow cooker chili and dan dan noodles, pasta with andouille sausage and one-pot beans, greens and grains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Anysphere, a Maker of A.I. Coding Software, Raises $105 Million
description: The company’s Cursor product, which can autocomplete programming code, helped the start-up draw a $2.5 billion valuation.
content: Anysphere, whose Cursor software uses artificial intelligence to help programmers code on the fly, plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised $105 million at a big jump in valuation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Chatta
title: Meta’s Decision to End Fact-Checking Could Have Disastrous Consequences
description: What happens on Meta’s platforms is more than just a matter of company policy.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, announced sweeping changes last week to the company’s approach to disinformation and hate speech. Its fact-checkers, Zuckerberg claimed, “have just been too politically biased, and have destroyed more trust than they’ve created.” Henceforth the company will be removing fewer posts; it will instead append “Community Notes.” Along the way, it will dramatically pare down its content restrictions on topics like immigration, potentially risking the same sorts of crises that have long eroded trust in the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Michael D. Shear
title: Israel and Hamas Are ‘on the Brink’ of Cease-Fire Agreement, Blinken Says
description: The negotiations, mediated by Qatar, Egypt and the United States, appear to be making progress after months of failed attempts to achieve a breakthrough.
content: Israel and Hamas are “on the brink” of agreeing on a cease-fire in Gaza and the release of hostages held there, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Tuesday, raising hopes for some respite to the violence after more than 15 months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun, Jin Yu Young and Victoria Kim
title: South Korea’s President Is Detained for Questioning
description: Yoon Suk Yeol became the first South Korean leader to be detained while in office, ending a tense standoff between his supporters and the authorities.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol became the first sitting South Korean leader to be detained for questioning by criminal investigators on Wednesday, striking a deal with massed law enforcement officials and ending a weekslong standoff over his declaration of martial law that thrust the country into a political crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: Laughing in the Dark
description: Are the most intense scenes in “Nosferatu,” “Anora” and “Babygirl” supposed to be funny? If not, why are people cracking up?
content: Perhaps you’ve heard them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Democrats Will Regret Helping to Pass the Laken Riley Act
description: This cruel and sweeping bill could upend our immigration system.
content: Democrats have a terrible habit, during moments of right-wing backlash, of voting for Republican legislation that they don’t seem to truly believe in and eventually live to regret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: Hochul Proposes Cutting Income Taxes for Middle-Class New Yorkers
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul used her State of the State speech to focus on affordability and crime, vowing to place a police officer on every overnight subway train.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York proposed slashing the state’s income tax for most residents as part of a sweeping populist agenda that she outlined in her State of the State address on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes and Ana Ley
title: Hochul Tries to Sell the Suburbs on Congestion Pricing
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is pointing out possible benefits of congestion pricing to suburban commuters, an influential voting bloc that could decide her political fortunes.
content: When congestion pricing made its long-awaited debut in New York City earlier this month, Gov. Kathy Hochul at first steered clear of praising one of the most significant policy acts of her tenure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 14, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 14, 2025.
content: An article on Monday about a priest who turned a cathedral bell tower into a ham-curing workshop to raise funds for the restoration of the cathedral’s antique organ misstated the given name of the former rector of the cathedral. He is Philippe Boyer, not Gilles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: The Airborne Flames
description: We explain why the Los Angeles fires have been so hard to contain.
content: More howling, whipping, fire-stoking winds have arrived in Los Angeles. They are expected to strengthen by dawn and may blow up to 70 miles per hour. Some gusts could rekindle parts of the major blazes tearing through the city’s hills and suburbs. Others could start new fires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korean Leader Shuns Trial as He Tries to Hold Off Detention
description: The Constitutional Court began hearings on whether to unseat Yoon Suk Yeol. But he remained in his fortified residence as investigators drew up plans to detain him.
content: The Constitutional Court of South Korea began formal deliberations on Tuesday to decide whether to unseat President Yoon Suk Yeol. The impeached leader stayed away, holed up in his fortified presidential compound where he is bracing himself for what his aides called a “siege attack” from up to 1,000 criminal investigators planning to detain him on insurrection charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Four Takeaways From Hegseth’s Confirmation Hearing
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary said nothing that would alienate the Republican senators on the Armed Services Committee.
content: Pete Hegseth’s four-hour hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday was strikingly contentious. Democrats derided him as blatantly unqualified to oversee the Defense Department’s three million employees and $849 billion budget. Republicans acknowledged that he was an unconventional pick, but said he was just what the Pentagon needed. And Senator Joni Ernst, the Iowa Republican who is an influential member of the panel, said after the hearing that she had been won over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Under the Radar: Venturing to Fantastical Universes With a Dodo and More
description: Stories from refugee children, gloriously morbid puppets and a rooster who defies a dictator. These are some of the offbeat offerings this January.
content: The new show “Dead as a Dodo” opens with the word “Bone!” Followed by “Death! Death! Death!” This isn’t the kind of dialogue you’d expect from something advertised for ages 7 and up, but no matter how young its audience members are, the company Wakka Wakka never underestimates their intelligence and willingness to engage in serious matters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘In the Shadow of Beirut’ Review: Surviving in Sabra and Shatila
description: This observational documentary tracks four families living in poverty in the capital of Lebanon.
content: Filmed from 2018 to 2022, the sobering documentary “In the Shadow of Beirut” tracks four families living in poverty in the capital of Lebanon. The directors, Stephen Gerard Kelly and Garry Keane, look at the bare facts of existence in a country that has endured, since 2019: an economic crisis, the coronavirus pandemic, a port explosion, Israel’s war with Hezbollah and a leadership vacuum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Hari Kumar
title: The World’s Largest Human Gathering Begins in India
description: About 400 million Hindu pilgrims from around the globe are expected to bathe in and around the Ganges in the religion’s biggest display of unity.
content: Tens of millions of Hindus are convening this week in what is expected to be the world’s largest human gathering, where a staggering number of devotees, tourists, politicians and celebrities take sacred dips at the convergence of two holy rivers in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg and Derek Arthur
title: How Trump’s ‘Favorite President’ Can Prepare Us for His Next Term
description: Argentina’s leader is inspiring America’s new right.
content: Argentina’s head of state, Javier Milei, is the latest inspiration for Donald Trump and his supporters, including Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy. As Trump prepares to return to the White House, the Times Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg explains what his admiration for Milei and his austerity policies might mean for Trump’s new administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Julia Jacobs
title: Art Collector Says He Lost Warhols and Harings to L.A. Fire
description: Ron Rivlin said he had lost about 30 works by Andy Warhol — and dozens more by other artists — when his Pacific Palisades home was destroyed.
content: As the flames grew closer and closer to his home in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles and his teenage daughter pleaded with him over the phone to evacuate, Ron Rivlin decided to flee, taking three Andy Warhols with him, all that he could carry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Passes Bill to Bar Trans Athletes From Female School Sports Teams
description: Republicans’ decision to push through the measure early in the new Congress indicated their belief that the issue is politically potent for them. Its future in the Senate is uncertain.
content: A divided House on Tuesday approved legislation that aims to bar transgender women and girls from participating in school athletic programs designated for female students, as Republicans sought to wring political opportunity from a social issue that helped them win the 2024 elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Werth
title: Biden Must Block Trump’s Sword of Retribution
description: He should issue pardons to critics of the incoming president.
content: Presidents have come in for their share of grief and more for pardoning people before they had even been convicted of crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis and Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea to Overhaul Runway Safety After Jeju Air Crash
description: The nation’s transport ministry reviewed structures near airport runways after the deadly crash of a Jeju Air flight late last month.
content: South Korea plans to alter structures near runways at several airports after last month’s Jeju Air crash, when a plane that landed on its belly skidded into a concrete wall before exploding into a fireball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Estimated Gaza Toll May Have Missed 25,000 Deaths, Study Says
description: Analysis found that more than 64,000 Palestinians may have been killed by traumatic injury in the first nine months of the war.
content: Deaths from bombs and other traumatic injuries during the first nine months of the war in Gaza may have been underestimated by more than 40 percent, according to a new analysis published in The Lancet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jack Smith’s What-if Report on Trump
description: Readers react to the special counsel’s report. Also: Israel, Gaza’s schools and the historians; “people pleasing”; Democrats’ fortunes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: A Neo-Nazi Helped Incite U.K. Riots. Elon Musk Criticized His Sentencing.
description: Andrew McIntyre, a British extremist who played a key role in fomenting last summer’s unrest, was sentenced last week to seven years in jail.
content: Hours after a deadly knife attack in the northern English town of Southport last July, Andrew McIntyre set up a Telegram channel called “Southport Wake Up.” Amid posts riddled with anti-Islamic, antisemitic and anti-immigrant abuse, he urged people to take to the streets, directing them to a mosque and calling for “war.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Cookies, Cocktails and Mushrooms on the Menu as Justices Hear Bank Fraud Case
description: In trying to find the line between false statements and misleading ones in the case of a Chicago politician, members of the Supreme Court posed colorful questions.
content: In a lively Supreme Court argument on Tuesday that included references to cookies, cocktails and toxic mushrooms, the justices tried to find the line between misleading statements and outright lies in the case of a Chicago politician convicted of making false statements to bank regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rhodes
title: Hegseth Is Dangerous but Not for the Reasons You Think
description: As secretary of defense, Hegseth would channel his boss’s blend of jingoism and anger to fundamentally alter the character of the military.
content: To state the obvious: As a former weekend “Fox & Friends” anchor, Army National Guard officer and leader of two small nonprofits, Pete Hegseth is unqualified to run a nuclear-armed organization with a budget approaching a trillion dollars. That’s the point. Donald Trump doesn’t want someone to effectively manage the Pentagon; he wants to disrupt it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Karoun Demirjian, Eric Schmitt, Sharon LaFraniere and John Ismay
title: Republicans Embrace Hegseth as Democrats Question His Fitness to Lead Pentagon
description: Pete Hegseth emerged from a Senate committee hearing with the support of the Republican Party intact following weeks of scrutiny over his qualifications and allegations of misconduct.
content: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to be defense secretary, faced sharp questions from Democrats, but no pointed ones from Republicans, at a contentious confirmation hearing on Tuesday that focused on his past statements on issues including Pentagon diversity efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Rosenfield, Brian Howey, Sarah Cohen and Rory Doyle
title: Where the Police Used a Taser on a Bible-Reading Great-Grandmother
description: A lack of state standards leaves Mississippi police and sheriff’s departments on their own to decide when to use stun guns, and many give officers a free hand.
content: Last summer, a Mississippi police officer approached Vivian Burks as she sat in her car at a local park reading the Bible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Moderate Drinking Raises Health Risks While Offering Few Benefits
description: A federal analysis that will shape the influential U.S. Dietary Guidelines questions alcohol’s overall benefits.
content: Among both men and women, drinking just one alcoholic beverage a day increases the risk of liver cirrhosis, esophageal cancer, oral cancer and injuries of various kinds, according to a federal analysis issued on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Publicity Hound
description: Lance Enfinger gets swept up in the game.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Hegseth Won’t Say Whether Sexual Assault, Drinking or Adultery Is Disqualifying
description: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to lead the Pentagon, rejected what he said were “false claims” about his conduct.
content: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon, on Tuesday repeatedly denied misconduct allegations against him and refused to say whether sexual assault, excessive drinking or marital infidelity should disqualify someone from serving as defense secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: castigate
description: This word has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word castigate has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 28 in “Its Future in Doubt, the Freewheeling ‘Inside the NBA’ Is on Edge Instead” by Tania Ganguli. The excerpt below refers to Ernie Johnson, the host of “Inside the NBA,” and Charles Barkley, an analyst on the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lloyd J. Austin III and Antony J. Blinken
title: Putin’s Plan for Peace Is No Peace at All
description: Now is the time for the United States to build on its historic success supporting Ukraine, not squander it.
content: President Vladimir Putin of Russia appalled the world with his full-scale invasion of Ukraine almost three years ago. He planned to topple Ukraine’s democratically elected government, install a Kremlin puppet regime and expose the West as weak, divided and diminished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: Shattered in the Fire: A Historic Black Haven
description: For Black residents, Altadena represented something more than suburban living. It was a foothold in generational prosperity.
content: Scenic and charming and tucked into the foothills, Altadena seemed like a secret just outside the reaches of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: After Loss, Tim Walz Faces Party’s Sinking Fortunes in Minnesota
description: Governor Walz’s party has lost control of the Minnesota Legislature and faces mounting criticism as a budget deficit looms.
content: Since returning to Minnesota after a failed bid for vice president, Gov. Tim Walz has kept a relatively low profile. He consoled deflated supporters with a speech at a high school, posed for photos with a turkey at the Minnesota State Capitol to mark Thanksgiving and flew to the Bahamas for a brief respite from the cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Female Senators Grill Hegseth Over Views on Women
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary had a more amicable exchange with Joni Ernst, a Republican, who is considered a key vote.
content: First came Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire. Then Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, Mazie Hirono of Hawaii, Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Tammy Duckworth of Illinois.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: In a First, the E.P.A. Warns of ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Sludge Fertilizer
description: Levels of PFAS in sewage sludge used as fertilizer can pose risks that sometimes exceed safety thresholds “by several orders of magnitude,” the agency said.
content: For the first time, the Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday warned that “forever chemicals” present in sewage sludge that is used as fertilizer can pose human health risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Katie Rogers
title: Michelle Obama Will Skip Trump’s Inauguration
description: Mrs. Obama also declined to attend the funeral of Jimmy Carter last week, which would have put her face-to-face with Mr. Trump.
content: Michelle Obama, the former first lady, will not attend the inauguration of President-elect Donald J. Trump, her office said in a statement on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘The Bunker’ Is a Chilly, Chilling True-Crime Documentary
description: The unsettling series, on Viaplay, brings a Swedish kidnapping victim to a detailed reconstruction of a bunker where she was held prisoner.
content: “The Bunker” is an unnerving true-crime documentary about an astonishing kidnapping, told in an unusual and unsettling way. Its three episodes arrive Thursday, on Viaplay, and depict not just a bizarre crime but also a made-for-TV therapeutic approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek and Sam Stanton
title: Ventura County Braces for Dangerous Fire Conditions Through Wednesday
description: Although the National Weather Service downgraded the severity of its forecast on Tuesday, forecasters expect higher wind gusts on Wednesday that could lead to “explosive fire growth.”
content: Just two months after grappling with a catastrophic fire that scorched more than 20,000 acres, Ventura County, Calif., was again bracing for dangerous fire conditions through Wednesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Héctor Tobar
title: Holding On to a Middle-Class Home in a Burning Los Angeles
description: Recovering from a disaster requires patience. And many working people — especially those whose wealth is tied up in their homes — might reconsider remaining.
content: Less than a month before fires began to ravage my hometown, State Farm sent me a bill. The oracles of risk foresaw an apocalypse in Los Angeles’s future. So they raised my home insurance premium by nearly 18 percent, even though I haven’t made a single claim in the quarter century I’ve lived in my neighborhood, Mount Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Families Struggle to Access the Palisades Fire Evacuation Zone
description: Hundreds of people trying to visit properties inside the zone in coastal Los Angeles were turned away on Monday. Frustration was mounting.
content: One woman hoped to salvage her father’s vintage music records from his coastal home. Another was desperate to see that her house was still standing. A third pleaded with a police officer to let her look for a pet turtle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittany Loggins
title: And Just Like That, Carrie Bradshaw’s Front Stoop Was Closed
description: A West Village homeowner was granted permission to build a gate on her house in an effort to stop overeager ‘Sex and the City’ fans from trespassing.
content: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday approved an application by a Manhattan homeowner to build a gate at the front of what she called her “celebrity staircase.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Strong winds are expected to return to Los Angeles, threatening to reverse some of the hard-fought gains that firefighters have made in battling the devastating blazes there. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: What to Know About ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Sludge Fertilizer
description: How to understand the E.P.A.’s new warning about PFAS levels in sewage sludge.
content: (Editors note: We are continuing to cover the Los Angeles fires. Scroll down for more on the latest.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Orders Inquiry After Complaints That Airline Ad Evoked 9/11
description: An advertisement meant to celebrate the resumption of flights to Paris showed a jet pointed toward the Eiffel Tower.
content: Pakistan’s prime minister on Tuesday ordered an investigation into how the country’s national airline approved an advertisement with an illustration that many on social media said was uncomfortably similar to imagery from Sept. 11, 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Hegseth Earned $6 Million From TV, Books and Paid Speaking Fees
description: Financial reports show the potential defense secretary’s pay from past speaking and writing, some of which provided fodder for senators during his confirmation hearing.
content: Pete Hegseth, the military veteran who is President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary, took in nearly $6 million as a Fox News broadcaster, author and paid speaker in recent years, according to a new financial filing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: You Are Cordially Invited to Our Wedding. But Not to Our Vows.
description: Some couples are finding more intimate ways to share their wedding pledges with each other: in private, in written notes — or even in sweats.
content: On Dec. 2, Rachel Birthistle and Roberto Bernasconi stood in front of their wedding guests at Passalacqua, a luxury hotel on the shore of Lake Como in Italy. The gathering was intimate, and the space charming. Everything felt traditional — until the vows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: The Mexican Official Accused of Hiding the Severity of the Border Crisis
description: When border crossings grew out of control in 2023, the U.S. pressured Mexico to do something. Officials rebuked the immigration chief and stripped him of a key power, an investigation shows.
content: The Americans were not happy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Wednesday Briefing: A Major U.S. Senate Hearing
description: Plus, mapping “The Lord of the Rings”
content: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump’s pick for defense secretary, faced hours of questioning yesterday during his Senate confirmation hearing. A vote to decide whether he will lead the Pentagon — a department with three million employees and an $849 billion budget — could come as soon as Monday. Read more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Catherine, Princess of Wales, Confirms She Is in Remission From Cancer
description: In an Instagram post on Tuesday, she wrote: “It is a relief to now be in remission and I remain focused on recovery.”
content: Catherine, Princess of Wales, said on Tuesday that her cancer was in remission, lifting a major cloud from the British royal family, which had struggled with serious health concerns for both her and King Charles III.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: How a Failed Basketball Player Made the First Rap Hit of the Year
description: The N.B.A. washout LiAngelo Ball debuted his track “Tweaker” on a livestream. It’s proving to be much more than a novelty.
content: How will rap hits get made in 2025? Judging by the year’s first unexpected hip-hop breakthrough, the answer is by accident, more or less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Dozens of Bodies Recovered From Illegal Mine in South Africa
description: The authorities had at one point limited the miners’ access to food, water and other supplies in a blockade that drew criticism from human rights groups.
content: The South African authorities said on Tuesday that they had pulled dozens of dead miners from a shuttered gold mine where they were working illegally until a blockade during which the police at one point cut off access to food, water and other supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: California Withdraws Some Requests for Tighter Climate Rules
description: State regulators said the measures would probably have been rejected by the Trump administration and that they would focus on homegrown legal strategies instead.
content: California has withdrawn requests that the Biden administration allow the state to enact limits on pollution from trucks, locomotives and ferries that are more strict than federal standards, on the expectation that the Trump administration would revoke them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: A Cure for Winter Blues? Try These Cozy New York Restaurants.
description: Cafe Kestrel in Brooklyn and Cocina Consuelo in Harlem can restore the spirit with warm service, cheery surroundings and deeply satisfying food.
content: It had been a terrible day. I woke up too late and too anxious. The heat in my apartment stopped working. All I wanted to do was wrap myself in blankets and watch a bad action movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Howey and Nate Rosenfield
title: In Taser Logs, a Practice That Long Went Unnoticed Is Revealed
description: An investigation found excessive Taser use in Mississippi to be widespread after reporters examined thousands of activations from department logs, many of which had never before been reviewed.
content: For nearly 20 years, a group of deputies at the Rankin County Sheriff’s Department in Mississippi used Tasers to torture people they suspected of using and dealing drugs. The group of officers — known as the Goon Squad — would raid homes, accuse those inside of crimes and shock them until they offered information or confessed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Revenge Is a Dish Best Served From the White House
description: What does it mean when Trump says, “I am your retribution”?
content: “I am your warrior,” Donald Trump declared in a 90-minute speech at a 2023 campaign event in Waco, Texas. “I am your justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Two Blistering Solos Raise the Stakes at Live Artery
description: Highlights so far of the 2025 contemporary dance festival, spread across New York City, are Symara Sarai and Leslie Cuyjet’s outstanding dances.
content: Symara Sarai, like a hurricane, tore up the stage in her aptly named solo “I want it to rain inside.” She made it storm. In another solo on another stage, Leslie Cuyjet, methodical and refined, commanded a different kind of attention with her flawless pacing and nuance. Her “For All Your Life” was a tour de force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Should Social Media Companies Be Responsible for Fact-Checking Their Sites?
description: Meta, the company that owns Facebook and Instagram, announced last week that it would end its longstanding fact-checking program. Is that a good idea?
content: Meta — the company that owns Facebook, Instagram, Threads and Whatsapp — announced on Jan. 7 that it would be ending its longstanding fact-checking program, a policy instituted to curtail the spread of misinformation across its social media apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s $1 Trillion Trade Surplus: What to Know as Trump Takes Office
description: Only a third of China’s trade surplus was with the United States, and only a third of the U.S. deficit was with China. That makes for tricky math for the president-elect.
content: China’s record trade surplus of almost $1 trillion last year has a nearly perfect mirror image on the other side of the world: an American trade deficit last year that is expected to clock in at around $1 trillion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: You Can Go Home Again, but Then You Have to Face Your Past
description: In “What Happened to the McCrays?” middle-aged high school sweethearts share an unbearable history.
content: Plaid shirts. Gruff men. Youth hockey. The girl next door. Black ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittany Loggins
title: You Can Have ‘Sex and the City,’ Just Not on the Front Stoop
description: The real-life owner of the Manhattan building where Carrie Bradshaw lived wants to erect a gate to deter overzealous fans from trespassing.
content: When a young location scout knocked on the door of 66 Perry Street in Manhattan’s West Village three decades ago, the homeowner who reluctantly agreed to allow filming on the front stoop couldn’t have imagined that the three-family building would become a cultural treasure better known as Carrie Bradshaw’s home in HBO’s “Sex and the City.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindi Leive
title: She Changed History, Then Erased Her Own
description: In “The Secret History of the Rape Kit,” Pagan Kennedy explores the tangled story of a simple but life-changing innovation, and the woman who fought for it.
content: In 2021, the Smithsonian acquired something called the Vitullo Evidence Collection Kit for Sexual Assault Examination. It was a 10-by-6-inch cardboard container filled mostly with items you could buy at any pharmacy, but for millions of American women, the “rape kit,” as this 1970s invention is now known, was a revolution in a box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rick Kuhn, 69, Dies; Convicted in a College Gambling Scandal
description: While playing basketball at Boston College, he participated in a point-shaving scheme with Henry Hill, the mobster later portrayed in the movie “Goodfellas.”
content: Rick Kuhn, a Boston College basketball player who was convicted for taking part in a headline-making point-shaving scandal that was largely organized by Henry Hill, the mobster played by Ray Liotta in the 1990 movie “Goodfellas,” died on Dec. 22 at his home in Ligonier, Pa. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 584
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Is Beijing Plotting a Musk Option for TikTok?
description: As the popular video app faces a ban in the United States, Chinese officials are said to be weighing options to save it — including a sale to the tech mogul.
content: As TikTok faces a countdown to a potential ban in the United States, Chinese officials are reportedly weighing an unexpected plan B: letting Elon Musk take over the popular video platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Dry January Is Driving Me to Drink
description: Do or do not, as Yoda might say. But please shut up about it, as I definitely would say.
content: The annual ritual known as Dry January is upon us. The monthlong ode to teetotalism started as a British health campaign in 2013, but it is now fully embedded in our American culture of self-branding. There are Dry January infographics, influencers, ad campaigns and incessant discussion about who is and is not drinking. The science is clear. Abstainers are doing a good thing for their health. I am happy for them. Still, despite a marked decline in my own taste for alcohol, I am not joining them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Pete Hegseth Dresses for Defense
description: The nominee for Secretary of Defense wore his patriotism on his sleeve during his confirmation hearing — and his belt, his socks, and his pocket square.
content: He may be President-elect Donald J. Trump’s most “unconventional” cabinet nominee (in the words of Senator Roger Wicker of Mississippi, the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee), but when Pete Hegseth took his seat in room G50 of the Dirksen Senate Office Building for his confirmation hearing as Secretary of Defense, he looked like a spit-polished officer in the Trump army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Starbucks Cracks Down: No Latte, No Lounging
description: Starbucks said visitors to the coffee shops would be required to buy something in order to use the restroom or stay in the store, as the company’s new chief executive responded to a decline in sales.
content: Starbucks will require people visiting its coffee shops to buy something in order to stay or to use its bathrooms, the company announced in a letter sent to store managers on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: The Magic of Swimming Lessons in Middle Age
description: I was never a great swimmer. After correcting a few common mistakes, I can now get a solid workout in the pool.
content: I’ve never been a good swimmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Depose Maduro
description: Combine a powerful incentive and a credible military threat to dislodge him and his cronies.
content: Donald Trump has set some grandiose foreign-policy goals for his second term, from buying Greenland to ending the war in Ukraine “in a day.” Here’s one goal that is overdue, morally right and in our national security interest: deposing the regime of Nicolás Maduro in Venezuela, through coercive diplomacy if possible or force if necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Frances Robles
title: Biden Will Remove Cuba From List of State Sponsors of Terrorism
description: The decision is the latest in a series of conflicting U.S. approaches to Cuba by different administrations.
content: President Biden will remove Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism, U.S. officials announced on Tuesday, as a part of a deal that is expected to free protesters jailed during a sweeping 2021 crackdown on dissent by the Communist government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Vast Trove of Arnold Schoenberg’s Music Is Destroyed in Fire
description: An estimated 100,000 scores by Schoenberg, the groundbreaking 20th-century composer, were destroyed when the publishing company his heirs founded burned down.
content: An estimated 100,000 scores and parts by the groundbreaking 20th-century composer Arnold Schoenberg were destroyed last week when the wildfires in Southern California burned down the music publishing company founded by his heirs. The company rents and sells the scores to ensembles around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Steve Bannon Asks to Replace His Lawyers Again, Possibly Delaying Trial
description: The longtime ally of Donald J. Trump faces state charges of bilking donors who gave money to build a border wall. His delay tactics mimic those of his patron.
content: With 43 days left before the start of Stephen K. Bannon’s trial in Manhattan, he asked a judge on Monday to be allowed to replace his lawyers for a second time, a move that could delay the trial. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Bus Monitor Guilty of Child Endangerment After 6-Year-Old Is Strangled
description: The bus monitor was acquitted of the more serious manslaughter charges she faced. She was on her phone and had earbuds in when a child seated behind her was strangled by a wheelchair’s harness.
content: A bus monitor who was looking at her cellphone and wearing earbuds when a disabled 6-year-old girl was strangled by her wheelchair harness was convicted of child endangerment on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: F.D.A. Proposes New Food Labels to Detail Sugar, Fat and Salt Levels
description: The agency issued designs for front-of-package lists that food companies would be required to include.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed requiring new nutrition labels on the front of food and beverage products, a long-awaited move aimed at changing eating habits associated with soaring rates of obesity and diet-related illness that are responsible for a million deaths each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Republicans Embraced Hegseth’s Bid to Lead the Pentagon
description: Also, Americans are flocking to a little-known Chinese app. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Pete Hegseth, Donald Trump’s pick for defense secretary, appeared at the Capitol today for a contentious four-hour confirmation hearing. Democratic senators repeatedly called him unfit to lead the Pentagon, but Republicans — who alone can confirm Hegseth — offered almost nothing but support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Who Will Succeed Jamie Dimon? The List of Contenders Narrows.
description: Jennifer Piepszak will become chief operating officer of JPMorgan, and said she would not seek the chief executive’s job. The current C.O.O., Daniel Pinto, plans to retire.
content: The slow-moving race to succeed Jamie Dimon at the helm of JPMorgan Chase has lost another entrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Old-Guard Republican Picked to Lead Texas House in Setback for Hard Right
description: The vote suggested that a period of political warfare between G.O.P. factions would continue to shape lawmaking in the state.
content: After months of bluster about a revolutionary new leadership coming to the Texas Legislature, the state’s Republican-dominated Statehouse on Tuesday selected a member of its old guard, Dustin Burrows, to be its next speaker, a surprising rebuke of the party’s aggressive hard-right faction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger, Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Meta to Cut 5% of Its Workers in New Round of Layoffs
description: The layoffs come as Mark Zuckerberg pushes to remake his company for the Trump era and prepares to co-host a gala for the president-elect’s inauguration.
content: Meta plans to lay off up to 5 percent of its employees based on performance ratings, according to an internal memo to workers on Tuesday viewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Palisades and Eaton Fires May Not Be Fully Extinguished for Weeks
description: The size of the huge blazes, along with difficult weather conditions and the emergence of smaller fires, have extended firefighters’ timelines. “It’s going to be a slow, arduous process,” one official said.
content: It may take weeks or longer for firefighters to fully extinguish the two most destructive fires that have ravaged parts of the Los Angeles area, fire officials warned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: Hundreds of Teachers Lost Homes in the L.A. Fires
description: Some teachers are scrambling to find temporary housing, even as they hope to return soon to their classrooms.
content: Hundreds of public schoolteachers are among the Southern Californians who lost their homes to raging wildfires in the last week. Some are scrambling to find places to live, even as they hope to return soon to their classrooms to restore some normality for their students — and for themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: ‘The Year of Flaco’ Will Celebrate a Beloved Owl
description: New York Historical is opening an exhibit of memorabilia of the eagle-owl, who died in February.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about an exhibition about Flaco, the Eurasian eagle-owl that captivated the city until his death last year. We’ll also get details on traffic in Manhattan during the first week of congestion pricing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: With Prizes and a Rainy Performance at the Olympics, a Pianist Rises
description: The 27-year-old musician Alexandre Kantorow has rapidly received worldwide attention. That hasn’t changed his approach to making music.
content: On the cover of his latest album, Alexandre Kantorow’s left arm falls back behind a piano bench. A wave builds slowly from his dangled palm, up through the straight line of his bare forearm, and crests around his shoulders before breaking, down through his arched neck and deeply bowed head, leaving, in the wash, his right hand at the keys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins Legaspi
title: Do I Need to Worry About Microplastics in Tea Bags?
description: Not all tea bags shed them. We asked experts if it’s risky to use the ones that do.
content: Q: I’ve heard there are microplastics in tea bags. Is that true? How can I stay safe and still enjoy my favorite beverage?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy X. Wang
title: Fix Your Glutes. Fix Your Life.
description: I didn’t appreciate their utility — and paid for it.
content: Two years is roughly how long it takes to achieve moderate fluency in a foreign language, to acquire an associate degree or to gestate an African elephant. This also happens to be the length of time that I recently spent pretending I could walk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Des Moines Art Center to Demolish Work and Pay Land Artist $900,000
description: The artist Mary Miss agreed to the settlement, ending a yearlong battle to save her work. The museum said her piece, which it had commissioned, had become a safety hazard.
content: A celebrated artwork by the environmental artist Mary Miss will be demolished by the museum that commissioned it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Saudi Arabia Said to Be Close to Deal With Billionaire’s Sports Network
description: A unit of the kingdom’s sovereign wealth fund would pay more than $1 billion to buy into DAZN, in the latest sign of its sports ambitions.
content: Saudi Arabia, long on the lookout for a global platform to showcase its sporting ambitions, is nearing the end of its search.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By May-lee Chai
title: A Secret Love Letter Sends Two Tunisian Families Reeling
description: The novel “A Calamity of Noble Houses” tries to piece together a fateful night that has reverberations for two families across four generations.
content: Little is known about the personal life of Tahar Haddad, the Tunisian writer, scholar and labor movement activist who died a political outcast in 1935, at just 36, after angering conservatives by calling for gender equality as a requisite for national rejuvenation and liberation. Taking his death as inspiration, Amira Ghenim’s sweeping, multigenerational historical novel “A Calamity of Noble Houses” is not just a fictionalized version of his life, but a kaleidoscopic portrait of Tunisian history, from colonial rule to the Nazi occupation to the country’s independence and the political struggles that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and John Koblin
title: Rashida Jones, MSNBC President, Steps Down
description: Rebecca Kutler, senior vice president for content strategy at MSNBC, will serve as the cable network’s interim president.
content: The president of MSNBC, Rashida Jones, stepped down on Tuesday, a major change at the cable network as it waits to see if loyal liberal viewers will tune back in when President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: In Kazakhstan, a Plain Space Energized by Color
description: With rents rising, a project manager bought a 388-square-foot apartment in the center of Almaty, Kazakhstan’s largest city, and leaned in on the design.
content: At the end of 2022, Kassym Baimukhametov was living in Almaty, Kazakhstan’s largest city, when he encountered a problem experienced by many: The rent was too damn high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: A Father and Son Called for Help Escaping as Flames Approached. None Came.
description: The man and his son, who both used wheelchairs, called for help in evacuating from the Eaton fire in California. They were found dead later that day, and now their family is asking what happened.
content: Anthony Mitchell called his daughter from his home in Altadena, Calif., on Wednesday morning and told her that he was OK.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: French Prime Minister Signals He Will Revisit Retirement Law That Led to Mass Protests
description: His government on shaky ground, Prime Minister François Bayrou offered to reopen debate on the measure, which raised the retirement age in an effort to stabilize the country’s finances.
content: Prime Minister François Bayrou of France said on Tuesday that he was open to changing the country’s unpopular pension law, which raised the retirement age to 64 from 62, as he sought to build support in Parliament and keep his government afloat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: California’s Insurance System Faces Crucial Test as Losses Mount
description: The California FAIR Plan, the state’s insurer of last resort, had just $377 million available last week to pay claims that could reach billions, officials said.
content: It’s too soon to know how the Los Angeles fires will change life in California, but it may heavily depend on the answer to a single question: Will a once-obscure insurance program run out of money?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The British Public Dislikes Elon Musk. He Can Still Sway Politics.
description: His influence is partly the result of a very online political establishment, and partly thanks to a right-leaning media that is hostile to Keir Starmer’s Labour government.
content: He is a deeply unpopular figure in Britain, according to opinion polls, and his social media channel has lost users in the country since he took it over in October 2022. Yet when Elon Musk put Britain in his cross hairs on X in recent weeks, pounding the political establishment over a decade-old child sex abuse scandal, he instantly catapulted the issue to the top of the news agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: Ex-Judge Forced Off Bench for Threats to Teens Is Back on Public Payroll
description: Erin P. Gall, who resigned from a New York State Supreme Court judgeship after footage showed her threatening to shoot Black teenagers, is now working as a lawyer for Herkimer County.
content: A former judge who resigned from the bench after threatening to shoot Black teenagers at a party has been hired for a key legal post by an upstate New York county.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca F. Elliott
title: Why Oil Industry Jobs Are Down, Even With Production Up
description: The industry is pumping ever more oil and natural gas, but it is doing so with only about three-quarters as many workers as it employed a decade ago.
content: For years, as oil and gas companies increased production, they hired lots of workers, enriching communities across the United States. That is no longer true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Mastercard Agrees to Settle Pay Discrimination Suit for $26 Million
description: The complaint accuses the company of underpaying female, Black and Hispanic employees compared with their male and white counterparts.
content: Mastercard is set to pay $26 million to settle accusations that the company has for years underpaid thousands of female, Black and Hispanic employees, according to an agreement filed in court on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett, Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
title: Jack Smith’s Accountability Effort Ends With More Freedom for Trump
description: The Justice Department now enters a second Trump administration with less authority to pursue a president than it has had in half a century.
content: In a closing argument he never got to make to a jury, Jack Smith, the former special counsel who investigated Donald J. Trump, insisted that his thwarted prosecution was righteous and that his investigators set an example “for others to fight for justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: In Global Market Rout, Britain Is the ‘Weakest Link’
description: Investors are demanding sharply higher yields on government bonds, threatening to upend the Labour Party’s plans to reinvigorate a stagnant British economy.
content: Governments around the world are uncomfortably watching their borrowing costs rise, following the lead of the U.S. Treasury market. But even in a global rout in bonds, Britain stands out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Capital One Is Accused of Cheating Customers Out of $2 Billion
description: Federal regulators said in a lawsuit on Tuesday that the giant bank deliberately underpaid savings account interest, even as rates rose.
content: The advertisement from Capital One had many of the same promises that other banks offer for high-yield savings accounts: There were no fees, no minimum deposits and the money would earn much more in interest than in traditional bank accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Gets Emotional Over the Los Angeles Fires
description: Kimmel said it was a “very scary, very stressful, very strange week here in L.A., where we work, where we live, where our kids go to school.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Carl Hulse, Emily Baumgaertner, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Special Counsel Report Says Trump Would Have Been Convicted, and Confirmation Hearings Begin
description: Plus, don’t go to this “Sex and the City” spot.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,306
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What We Know About the Proposed Gaza Cease-Fire Agreement
description: Diplomats expressed cautious optimism on Tuesday that an agreement between Israel and Hamas may be within reach. But they also warned that it was not signed yet.
content: After more than 15 months of nearly uninterrupted fighting in Gaza, diplomats trying to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas expressed cautious hope on Tuesday that a deal could finally be within reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Schneider
title: Can the Only Grocery Store in a Rural Michigan Town Stay Independent?
description: The owners of Honor Family Market are ready to retire. A buyer would face the tight margins of a small business and competition against the giant chains and discount stores.
content: The town of Honor, in northern Michigan, doesn’t have too many places to shop for food. The only grocery store in town is Honor Family Market, one of a shrinking number of independent grocers left in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King, Benjamin Oreskes and Jay Root
title: 5 Takeaways from Hochul’s State of the State Address
description: Child care, housing costs and public safety were the New York governor’s top issues as she outlined her policy plans for the year and for a re-election fight in 2026.
content: In her fourth State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York laid the foundation for her re-election message, hoping to connect with disaffected Democrats who voted against the party in the last presidential election and to woo them back as she stares down a tough fight for a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Hegseth Spars with Senator Over What He Meant by Slang Term
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary used a generally unflattering term to criticize legal officers in the military.
content: One of the stranger moments in a confirmation hearing on Tuesday for Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon, was when a senator asked the former Fox News host to define the word “jagoff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Kate Conger
title: S.E.C. Sues Elon Musk Over Twitter-Related Securities Violations
description: Regulators filed a lawsuit in federal court stemming from Mr. Musk’s $44 billion purchase of the social media company now called X.
content: U.S. securities regulators sued Elon Musk in federal court in Washington on Tuesday in an enforcement action arising from his $44 billion purchase of Twitter, now called X.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: As the Eaton Fire Still Burns, Locals Gather Seeds to Regrow
description: In Altadena, a network of home gardeners answer the call to build a free “library” of plant seeds.
content: When Nina Raj saw the sky glow orange outside her Altadena home as the Eaton fire approached last Tuesday, the first thing that she packed for evacuation was her seed collection: Matilija poppy seeds, Engelmann oak acorns, California buckeye, sage and buckwheat seeds, along with so many others she had gathered around Eaton Canyon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle
title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Wildfires, TikTok, Perry the Donkey
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

author: By Jesse Wegman and Lee Drutman
title: How to Fix America’s Two-Party Problem
description: Proportional representation could help restore American democracy.
content: Proportional representation could help restore American democracy.

title: Read the Special Counsel’s Report on the Trump Election Case
description: The former special counsel Jack Smith stood behind his prosecution of President-elect Donald J. Trump in a report released early Tuesday.
content: The former special counsel Jack Smith stood behind his prosecution of President-elect Donald J. Trump in a report released early Tuesday.

title: Who’s Investigating South Korea’s President?

content: A visual guide to the multiple government agencies that are investigating whether President Yoon Suk Yeol committed insurrection.

author: By Samuel Granados
title: The Floods This Time: In the Mediterranean, Climate Change Is Already Here
description: Short, heavy rainfall is typical of the Mediterranean, but nothing is typical about what has been happening there recently.
content: Short, heavy rainfall is typical of the Mediterranean, but nothing is typical about what has been happening there recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy White
title: Many of California’s Most Destructive Fires Were Caused by Power Lines
description: Officials are probing whether electrical equipment sparked the Los Angeles fires. Such infrastructure has ignited vast destruction in recent years.
content: Officials are probing whether electrical equipment sparked the Los Angeles fires. Such infrastructure has ignited vast destruction in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Howey, Nate Rosenfield, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, David Jouppi and Ben Powell
title: How Mississippi Police Taser Use Leads to Abuse and Injury
description: A lack of statewide standards leaves many Mississippi police and sheriff’s departments on their own to decide protocols for stun guns. The reporters Brian Howey and Nate Rosenfield explain their investigation for The New York Times and Mississippi Today on how local departments have given their officers a free hand.
content: A lack of statewide standards leaves many Mississippi police and sheriff’s departments on their own to decide protocols for stun guns. The reporters Brian Howey and Nate Rosenfield explain their investigation for The New York Times and Mississippi Today on how local departments have given their officers a free hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Investigators in South Korea Attempt to Detain Impeached President
description: Criminal investigators began a second operation early Wednesday to detain the impeached president, Yoon Suk Yeol, for questioning in connection with insurrection charges.
content: Criminal investigators began a second operation early Wednesday to detain the impeached president, Yoon Suk Yeol, for questioning in connection with insurrection charges.
